title: Arsenal hero slams Man Utd midfielders Fred and Scott McTominay following Liverpool draw
text:
Arsenal legend Charlie Nicholas has slammed two Manchester United players (Picture: Getty)

Arsenal legend Charlie Nicholas has criticised Fred and Scott McTominay, claiming the Manchester United pair ‘cannot pass the ball’.

Brazilian midfielder Fred has endured a hugely disappointing start to his career at Old Trafford following a £52million move from Shakhtar Donetsk last year.

The 26-year-old has been unable to cement a place in Manchester United’s starting XI, receiving substantial criticism from Red Devils fans over the past 16 months.

Academy graduate McTominay has a better reputation amongst United fans but Nicholas says he is still another player who lacks technical ability.

Looking ahead to Manchester United’s Europa League clash against Serbian outfit Partizan on Thursday, the Gunners hero told Sky Sports: ‘This is another difficult game for Man Utd.

‘It was a Jose Mourinho-style performance against Liverpool.

‘I can never remember United, even when I have seen them on the back foot and having poor times, seeing them knock 50-60 yards to get five or six seconds breathing space. United nearly won ugly.

‘Anthony Martial is fit and I think he will start, while Marcus Rashford started, scored and played well against Liverpool.

‘Ole Gunnar Solskjaer will want to go to a back four, but their midfield cannot keep the ball. Scott McTominay and Fred are grafting but they cannot pass the ball.

Nicholas claims Scott McTominay ‘cannot pass the ball’ (Picture: Getty)

‘It is another awkward night for Manchester United, but 1-1 would be a decent result for them and that is saying something.’

Solskjaer’s Manchester United held Premier League leaders Liverpool to a draw at Old Trafford on Sunday, with Adam Lallana cancelling out Marcus Rashford’s first-half opener.

The draw means the Red Devils remain just 14th in the table, two points above the relegation zone, while Manchester City have closed the gap on Liverpool to six points.
